description: perplex +‎ -ity, from Middle French perplexité or post-classical Latin perplexitas ‘entanglement’, from perplexus.

entries.meaning: The state or quality of being perplexed; puzzled or confused.

examples: The Emperor, who was by then a focus of unresolvable perplexities, stood providing a strongly contrary appearance.

entries.meaning: In information theory, a measurement of how well a probability distribution or model predicts a sample.
